awd_abstract_narration:
During the summer of 2021, the Polymath Jr. program will provide research opportunities to hundreds of undergraduates from different backgrounds. It will also train a group of graduate students in mentoring undergraduate research. This highly inclusive program will support students who do not have research opportunities, due to the pandemic or for other reasons. It is an online program that employs modern virtual tools: meetings with Zoom, a dedicated Wiki site, Overleaf, and a Discord server.

The program consists of at least 12 research projects in a variety of mathematical subfields: number theory, combinatorics, representation theory, commutative algebra, complex analysis, and more. Each project includes a professor who is an expert in the relevant field, additional graduate student mentors, and 20-30 undergraduate students. Some projects focus on proof writing, others involve programming, applied problems, exploring large spaces of examples, and so on. The goal of this variety is to provide opportunities for students with very different interests and backgrounds.

https://geometrynyc.wixsite.com/polymathreu

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the Polymath Jr program is to provide research opportunities to undergraduate students who are interested in mathematics but have no other opportunities. During the summer of 2021, the program supported approximately 360 students. These students were divided among 17 research projects in a wide variety of mathematical subfields, according to their preferences. Each project was run by a professor who is an expert in the field, had graduate students or postdocs as additional mentors, and consisted of about 21 students. The entire work was done online, relying on Zoom, A dedicated Wiki server, Discord, Overleaf, and more.

The research projects resulted in many manuscripts, and we expect most of those to appear in research journals. According to the end-of-program survey, the participants were very happy about their experience in the program. More importantly, many students who did not have opportunities before used the program to demonstrate their mathematical abilities and potential, to learn what mathematical research looks like, or to accomplish other goals. Beyond the research work, participants were also trained in giving talks, writing proofs, using mathematical software, applying to graduate school, and more.

Providing advanced mathematical opportunities to hundreds of students has multiple positive outcomes. Students who did not have opportunities before and demonstrated their enthusiasm and potential rely on the program to continue to graduate school or to other advanced opportunities. Other participants spent less time in the program and relied on it to get a first impression of mathematical research and whether they wish to pursue it in the future. Most cases are between these two extremes.

Beyond supporting more students on their way to graduate school and math-related careers, the program increases STEM-literacy in society. Participants will continue to careers in most parts of society, and spread their enthusiasm about mathematics. In particular, having more schoolteachers who understand what mathematical research is could make a significant impact.

The 2021 Polymath Jr program also trained graduate students in mentoring undergraduate research. These graduate students participated in a pre-program workshop, attended regular group meetings, and had personal mentors for undergraduate mentoring. They received hands-on experience by working as additional mentors in Polymath Jr projects. We encourage these graduate students to pursue more undergraduate mentoring in the future and help them obtain such jobs. Thus, the program has a long-lasting effect on undergraduate mentoring.

The 2022 Polymath Jr program demonstrates the success of the 2021 program. Many students from the 2021 program joined the 2022 program to participate in another research project. For a few, this was the third summer in the program. Two past mentors who just received tenure-track jobs joined as professors who run their own 2022 Polymath Jr projects. Similarly, several past undergraduate participants are now graduate mentors in the program. People who participated in previous programs are enthusiastic to support younger generations of students.
